PostValue.explanation: This is a practical, evidence-based donor guide promoting high-impact global health interventions and reputable evaluators (GiveWell, HLI, etc.). For the EA community it is moderately important: it consolidates actionable recommendations that guide donations and careers, but it is not novel or foundational to EA theory. For general humanity it is somewhat useful — it can steer philanthropic resources toward life‑saving, cost‑effective programs — but it is not transformational at the level of global policy or civilization‑scale priorities.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Temper and unpack the “~$5,000 to save a life” claim. As written this reads like a single, precise fact but it depends heavily on which interventions, locations, and assumptions are used. Add a one-sentence qualifier (or a short parenthetical) that points to GiveWell’s detailed breakdown, states the main assumptions (marginal lives saved, baseline mortality, time horizon), and gives a plausible uncertainty range or notes that the figure varies substantially by program and scale. This prevents readers from overgeneralising and reduces the risk of being challenged on a technical point. 

2) Directly summarise the strongest systemic counterarguments and your concise responses. The current section links to other pages but dismisses concerns (e.g. aid dependency, crowding out, governance distortions, fungibility, market effects) without a short, evidence-backed summary. Add 2–3 short sentences (one per major objection) that say: what the objection is, why it could plausibly matter, and the most important evidence or reasoning that makes you still recommend donating (with links). This makes the post more robust to quick objections and saves readers from having to click through to defend the post. 

3) Be clearer about your selection methodology and update cadence. Readers will want to know how and how often you evaluate charities, what criteria matter most (cost-effectiveness, evidence, scalability, risk of harm), and why the recommendation list changed this year. Add one short paragraph that states the key selection criteria, notes any conflicts of interest (or absence thereof), and links to the full methodology. This increases credibility without much extra length.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: This feedback targets three real weaknesses that could embarrass the author if challenged: an over-specified ‘$5,000 to save a life’ claim, skimpy treatment of common systemic objections, and lack of a concise statement of selection criteria/update cadence. Fixing these would substantially increase accuracy, credibility, and defensibility without adding much length — they’re important but not fatal to the page’s main thesis, hence a high but not maximal score.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: "EA Handbook" appears to be a collective/resource title or pseudonymous/organizational author (a guide for newcomers) rather than a single prominent individual. It is reasonably known within EA/rationalist circles as a reference but not a well‑known author or frequent public figure; it has virtually no recognition outside the EA community.

PostClarity.explanation: Well-structured and easy to follow: clear headings, concrete statistics, and many source links make the central point (donations to global health are high-impact) convincing and actionable. Weaknesses: a bit long and occasionally repetitive, with some jargon (e.g. "subjective well‑being", "astronomical number") and brief promotional asides that could use concise definitions or tighter phrasing for novices.

PostNovelty.explanation: The post largely summarizes well-known, widely circulated EA arguments and resources (GiveWell, Our World In Data, Founders Pledge, cost‑effectiveness claims like ~$5k per life saved, etc.). For EA readers this is very familiar material and adds little new analysis or original claims. For the general public it’s moderately novel as a concise, evidence‑based framing and curated recommendation list, but the core ideas (global health is high impact; recommended charities; common objections) are not original.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post is well structured and presents a clear, internally consistent argument — poverty and preventable disease are large problems, there exist cost‑effective interventions, and donors can meaningfully help today. It cites credible organisations (Our World in Data, WHO, GiveWell, Founders Pledge, Happier Lives Institute) and explicitly acknowledges plausible alternative priorities and common objections. Weaknesses: Many empirical claims are supported by links to secondary summaries rather than primary studies or quantitative uncertainty estimates; the post does not discuss heterogeneity of effects, scalability constraints, administrative overhead, or important assumptions (e.g., value weighting across beneficiaries, discounting, spillovers). Some cause areas (education, mental health, women’s empowerment) are asserted to be effective with limited in‑text evidence and nuance. Overall, the thesis is reasonably well supported for a high‑level advocacy piece, but would need more detailed, primary‑evidence and uncertainty analysis to be judged exceptional.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most of the post’s major empirical claims are accurate and verifiable from authoritative sources.  Evidence that supports the post includes: (1) ~700 million people in extreme poverty in 2015 (World Bank projection / Our World in Data), (2) large annual death burdens from preventable diseases (WHO malaria, TB and diarrhoeal disease fact sheets/reports), and (3) GiveWell’s public cost‑effectiveness estimates (GiveWell and Our World in Data cite ~USD 4–6k per life saved for GiveWell’s top programs, so the ~USD 5,000 figure is a reasonable rounded summary). The recommended charities and funds listed match Giving What We Can’s published recommendations. Main weaknesses/nuances: the mental‑illness statistic (“10.5% of the global disease burden”) is imprecise/outdated depending on definition and year — older GBD/WHO summaries reported ~10–11% for the broader category of mental/neurological/substance disorders in earlier GBD rounds, whereas GBD 2019 reports ~4.9% of global DALYs attributable to mental disorders (and ~14.6% of global YLDs); GiveWell’s “~$5k per life” is a rounded, program‑dependent estimate and varies by charity, location and funding marginality. Overall: well‑supported but with a few important definitional/time‑frame clarifications needed.
